Executive Summary for Rich Products Niles, Illinois Facility

The Site has developed this program in accordance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA's) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (CAPP) of the Clean Air Act, as amended (CAAA), a.k.a., the Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule, which is codified at 40 CFR 68; and the United States Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (HHCs) standard (PSM standard), which is codified at 29 CFR 1910.119. The program is designed to inform all Site employees (hereafter referred to as Associates) of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates in the event of a release or spill (i.e., emergency response plan, management of change procedures, preventative maintenance program, associate training, etc.).

The Site has taken a more conservative approach in calculating the worst case scenario (see below) and has voluntarily submitted this correction.


RPC is guided by a set of core values that include:

-- Cherish Our Culture - Work, learn and celebrate together;
-- Innovate - Imagine what's possible and create what's valued;
-- Be the Trusted First Choice - Listen, understand and deliver for customers like no other company;
-- Better Our Communities - Devote time and talent where we work and live; and
-- Do What's Right - No matter what.

RPC is committed to an irrevocable obligation to act responsibly in every decision made and with every person encountered. RPC understands it is a trusted steward of its business relationships, its environment and the communities in which it serves. RPC holds itself to the highest set of standards and is about doing what's right...no matter what.


FACILITY DESCRIPTION

Rich Products Corporation's (RPC's) Niles facility (RPC-NLS or Site) is located at 6200 West Mulford Street in the Village of Niles, Cook

County, Illinois and is situated in in an area zoned as limited manufacturing. The Site occupies an approximately 70,000 square-foot structure that is located on 2.5-acres of land. The Site was originally developed in 1960 and has been owned and operated by RPC since 1994.

The Site is a non-dairy frozen food manufacturing facility. The Site's North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 311991 (Perishable Prepared Food Manufacturing).

As part of the refrigeration system to freeze the non-dairy foods produced, the Site handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical, as defined in the USEPA's CAPP and OSHA's PSM standard, in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold for anhydrous ammonia in a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. The Site is registered to Program Level 3 under the CAPP program.

The anhydrous ammonia is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system. The Site's engine room houses the majority of the refrigeration machinery.


OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

In calculating the worst case release scenario, Site personnel have conservatively utilized 100 percent of the largest vessel as the amount released. However, under no circumstances is this analysis intended to indicate that Site personnel fill any vessel to this extent.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION

While there are few long-term environmental consequences to ammonia use, it can present health hazards if handled improperly. RPC has developed a comprehensive safety program in compliance with OSHA and EPA requirements to ensure the responsible management of the ammonia onsite (the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program, respectively). All refrigeration Associates receive operator training, safe work practices training and training on the standard operating procedures (SOPs). Safety meetings are conducted to further protect As

sociates and the community as a whole.

The Site's prevention program is designed to inform all Associates of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates and the community in the event of a release or spill.

The Site endeavors to eliminate accidents and health hazards to Associates, customers, and the community by having procedures in place to provide Associates educational training, safe working conditions, and the means to increase awareness of potential dangers both on and off the job. In addition to the ongoing inspection and maintenance of the refrigeration system, wherever possible refrigeration system components are located in areas that are not as likely to become damaged (i.e., tanks and pipe runs are placed away and protected from forklift and truck traffic). RPC's objective is to prevent unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could potentially expose Associates and others to serious hazards. An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire system. Workplace and process safety are major concerns to management and Associates alike. The prevention and mitigation of unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could expose Associates and the community to serious hazards is of primary concern.

The Site has incorporated many safety features in the design of the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Site's ammonia system is continuously monitored by automated control systems that shutdown pump and the components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the system is equipped with pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels and most, if not all, additional locations within the ammonia s

ystem where ammonia could become trapped.

RPC considers the health and safety of each Associate as its most important responsibility. It is our policy to provide a healthy and safe work environment. This facility follows operating practices that safeguard all associates and result in safe working conditions while maintaining efficient operations.

Safety is the responsibility of all Associates. Each associate is expected to comply with the requirements of RPC's Standards for Safety Performance. Management is responsible for the implementation, communication, documentation, and necessary training. The Associate is responsible for implementation, communication, and practices of the program. Management is committed to maintain a high level of interest in health and safety throughout this facility. This commitment extends to the associates and their involvement in preventing accidents.

RPC has established its Health and Safety Program to insure that:

-- Associates work in a healthy and safe environment.
-- Associates are trained on safe work practices.
-- Associates practice safe work habits.
-- Management and associates are both involved in the program.
-- There is constant communication between all Associates on safety issues.
-- Compliance with all regulatory agencies is maintained.

Major safety features at the Site include:

-- Installation of ammonia leak detectors in processing areas and the engine room;
-- Remote emergency shutdown switches for the refrigeration system;
-- Fire sprinklers throughout the Site;
-- Component specific safety shutdowns of the refrigeration system, and
-- A proprietary Refrigeration Energy Management System (REMS) computer monitoring system.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Site has not had a reportable incident involving anhydrous ammonia within the previous five years.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Site is equipped with an emergency warning system. Alarms are placed throughout the Site to alarm

personnel of an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia or other emergencies that may be encountered. RPC has developed specific procedures to be followed in the event of release. These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so. The Site is staffed 24 hours, 7 days per week.

In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release, Site Associates will evacuate and contact the Village of Nile's Fire Department for emergency response services.

Site Associates have developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in accordance with the provisions of 29 CFR 1910.38.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Site recognizes that the implementation of this program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operation at the Site. As such, the prevention program will evolve as RPC continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for the employees and the surrounding community.
